questions.text: A 45-year-old asymptomatic male presents with a grade II diastolic murmur on routine physical exam. He has no other symptoms and physical examinations showed no abnormalities. ECG and chest X-ray are normal . What is the next best step for evaluation of his murmur?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Echocardiogram

questions.text: Mr. Vishal, a 67-year-old owner of a wildly successful chain of fastfood restaurants. He complains of shortness of breath with exertion, lower extremity edema, and awakening at night feeling acutely short of breath. You wish to assess his volume status, and know that jugular venous pulse (JVP) assessment is the single most important bedside measurement to aid in this. Which of the following is true regarding the measurement?

options.label: A
options.text: Measurement of the elevation of the top of the jugular venous pulsation and the sternal inflection point (angle of Louis) will provide a highly accurate measurement of central venous pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: If done properly, the angle of inclination matters little to the measurement of JVP.

options.label: C
options.text: In normal patients, the JVP rises with inspiration due to the augmented volume loading of the right heart.

options.label: D
options.text: Venous pulsations above the clavicle in the sitting position are abnormal.

questions.correct_answer: D. Venous pulsations above the clavicle in the sitting position are abnormal.
questions.explanation: Ans. D)

questions.text: A 75-year-old man who presents to your emergency department appearing quite ill. His family says he has not had his normal energy for the last 6 months, and they noted he appeared confused and lethargic for the last day or two. As you take a history from the family, you palpate the patient’s radial pulse and notice a regular beat-to-beat variability of pulse amplitude although his rhythm is regular. Indeed, as you later take his blood pressure, you note that only every other phase I (systolic) Korotkoff sound is audible as the cuff pressure is slowly lowered, and that this is independent of the respiratory cycle. Based on this, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Severe left ventricular dysfunction

questions.text: You are working in the emergency department when a 65-year-old woman with a history of recently diagnosed lymphoma who has not started treatment or undergone staging yet. On presentation, she is markedly diaphoretic and dyspneic. SBP 70mm Hg on palpation, heart rate is 110 beats/min, and her radial pulse becomes difficult to palpate on inspiration. ECG of the patient is shown below. What pathology is present and accountable for her shock state?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Pericardial effusion with tamponade

questions.text: You are performing a right heart catheterization in a 45-year-old man with suspected pulmonary hypertension. You do indeed note elevated pulmonary arterial pressures, with a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 45 mmHg. The patient is not hypoxemic. However, you also note the following oxygen saturations from each cardiac chamber: Superior vena cava—61% Inferior vena cava—65% Right atrium—85% Right ventricle—84% Pulmonary artery—84% You suspect which of the following based on this data?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunting

options.label: C
options.text: Ventricular septal defect with left-to-right shunting

options.label: D
options.text: Ventricular septal defect with right-to-left shunting

questions.correct_answer: A. Atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunting
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunting

questions.text: You are seeing Mr. Johnson who is a 24-year-old previously healthy marathon runner. He is in for his employer-required physical examination. ECG is shown below. What’s the likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block

options.label: C
options.text: Mobitz type II, second-degree heart block

questions.correct_answer: B. Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes mellitus, and osteoporosis presents to the emergency department after a fall at home followed immediately by intense left hip pain. She was found by a neighbor after several hours. The patient cannot remember if she lost consciousness. She is exquisitely tender to palpation over the left hip, and her leg is shortened and externally rotated. Her mucous membranes are dry and her skin tents easily. Blood pressure is 170/80 and her heart rate is 130 beats/min. She is dyspneic and wheezing. ECG taken and shown below. What is the most appropriate first step for her tachycardia?
questions.correct_answer: D. Pain control and IV hydration
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Pain control and IV hydration

questions.text: A 66-year-old man, recently diagnosed with multiple myeloma after presenting with fatigue from anemia and lower back pain. Further evaluation found malignant bone lesions in his thoracic and lumbar spine. He was started on multi-agent treatment 6 weeks ago and comes in for follow-up. He has been feeling well with decreased pain and denies any new side effects from treatment. He wants to know if his disease is responding to the current therapy. Which test would be the most helpful in assessing his response to treatment?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Monoclonal immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman with metastatic thyroid cancer. Her cancer is progressing now after three different therapies. Her oncologist recommends that she join a clinical trial. After searching on the Internet, she finds a trial that she is eligible for and sounds interesting. The trial is testing a new drug, drug x. The main end point of the trial is to determine the maximally tolerated dose of drug x. What phase of drug development is drug x currently in?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Phase I

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a 40 pack-year smoking history. He finally quit last year when he started to develop shortness of breath. His shortness of breath has continued to progress to the point where he is short of breath even at rest. He did not want to go to the doctor, but his daughter finally convinced him to go to the emergency room. There CT imaging revealed a 3-cm left-sided peripheral nodule with three ipsilateral enlarged lymph nodes and a larger left pleural effusion. Lung cancer is suspected, so biopsy of the lung nodule is obtained. What is the next best step in management and why?

options.label: A
options.text: Await pathology results because if the patient has a KRAS mutation, targeted treatments can be offered.

options.label: B
options.text: Await pathology results because if the patient has an EGFR mutation, targeted treatments can be offered.

options.label: C
options.text: Consult medical oncology for emergent chemotherapy while hospitalized.

options.label: D
options.text: Consult radiation oncology for emergent radiation therapy while hospitalized.

questions.correct_answer: B. Await pathology results because if the patient has an EGFR mutation, targeted treatments can be offered.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Await pathology results because if the patient has an EGFR mutation, targeted treatments can be offered.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman returns to your clinic after being “lost to follow-up” for 3 years. She reports that she was diagnosed with left-sided, stage I, estrogen/progesterone receptor– positive breast cancer 3 years ago. She was then treated with surgery, radiation, and adjuvant hormonal therapy. She did not receive chemotherapy. She reports that she has been doing well, without any symptoms currently. Her last mammogram was 15 months ago. Her CA 27-29 level was 40 U/mL at the time of diagnosis. Which of the following tests would be recommended for her now?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Mammogram

questions.text: You are caring for a 17-year-old boy after repair of muscular ventricular septal defect; he is postoperative day number 1 and doing well. The nurse pages you that he suddenly had a rise in heart rate. Given your clinical savvy and knowledge gleaned from hours of study, you suspect junctional ectopic tachycardia (JET). All of the statements regarding JET are true EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: It is due to reentry within the atrioventricular node (AV).

options.label: C
options.text: It is more common in children.

options.label: D
options.text: It may commonly be seen after cardiac surgery or ablation procedures in the AV node.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is due to reentry within the atrioventricular node (AV).
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It is due to reentry within the atrioventricular node (AV).

questions.text: An 86-year-old man with long-standing heart failure. He presents with the acute onset of palpitations, weakness, dizziness, and dyspnea. On arrival, his skin is cool and clammy, and he is sleepy. He will arouse to a loud voice, but he is not oriented and quickly becomes obtunded. His heart rate is irregularly irregular at 160 beats/min and his blood pressure is 50/30. STAT 12-lead electrocardiogram confirms atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Which of the following is the most reasonable next therapeutic step?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 200-J QRS-synchronous shock

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with known sickle cell anemia is admitted to the intensive care unit with diffuse body pain, shortness of breath, fever, and cough. He started having a bone pain crisis 1 day ago and tried to treat it at home with oral hydration. On examination, his blood pressure and heart rate are elevated, and he is in obvious pain and respiratory discomfort. His room air SaO2 is 83% and increases to 91% on a nonrebreather oxygen face mask. His chest radiograph shows bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates. This is his third similar episode in the last 12 months. All of the statements regarding his condition are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic therapy with oral hydroxyurea should be considered.

options.label: B
options.text: He is having sickle cell acute chest syndrome.

questions.correct_answer: C. He should receive daily sildenafil.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) He should receive daily sildenafil.

questions.text: Mr. Anbu, 58 years old male is admitted with an anterior myocardial infarction after watching India losing in a cricket World cup final again. He undergoes timely revascularization with a stent to the left anterior descending artery. In the intensive care unit afterward, you notice frequent premature ventricular contractions but no ventricular tachycardia. You draw a set of electrolytes that finds a potassium of 3.2 mEq/L (normal 3.5–5.1) and magnesium of 1.1 mEq/L (normal 1.3–3.1). All of the following are indicated in this setting EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) IV lidocaine

questions.text: A 47-year-old post-menopausal woman is seen for onset of severe dyspnea over the last few weeks. She reports no preceding chest pain, cough, sputum, or fever, although she does report leg swelling. Physical examination is notable for a blood pressure of 145/78 mmHg and heart rate of 123 beats/min. Exophthalmos is present as well as bilateral inspiratory crackles approximately occupying one-third of the lower chest with neck vein distention. She has a third heart sound with no murmur. Bilateral lower extremity edema is also present with warm extremities and a fine hand tremor. Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiologic explanation for her heart failure?

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic systemic hypertension with resultant left ventricular hypertrophy and non-systolic heart failure

options.label: C
options.text: Myocardial infarction with depressed left ventricular systolic function

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thyrotoxicosis with high-output state.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyrotoxicosis can cause high-output heart failure. Recognizing the signs and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis is crucial for prompt diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Thyrotoxicosis can cause high-output heart failure.
  • ➤ Recognizing the signs and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis is crucial for prompt diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ In patients presenting with heart failure, consider a broad differential diagnosis, including less common causes like thyrotoxicosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man returns to the acute care clinic complaining of 1 day of worsening malaise, weakness, abdominal pain, and discolored dark urine. He was at the clinic yesterday where he was diagnosed with a possible staphylococcal skin carbuncle and treated with empiric trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. His physical examination is notable for mild jaundice, normal vital signs, and no focal findings other than the carbuncle in his left axilla. His complete blood count shows that his hemoglobin has fallen from 13 to 8 g/dL and his bilirubin has gone from normal to 3.0 mg/dL. His urine dipstick is positive for bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his new anemia?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency

questions.text: On yearly labs done to follow a 40-year-old patient with a history of iron-deficiency anemia, you notice the development of new thrombocytosis with a platelet count of 750 × 109/L. All of the following statements regarding thrombocytosis are true EXCEPT

options.label: B
options.text: Patients with essential thrombosis have a similar survival compared with the general population.

options.label: C
options.text: The incidence of thrombosis in this patient is no higher than age-matched controls.

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment with aspirin should be started immediately.

questions.correct_answer: D. Treatment with aspirin should be started immediately.
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Treatment with aspirin should be started immediately.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. He is found to have an elevated serum B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP). In addition to heart failure, all of the following may also cause an elevation in BNP EXCEPT:

options.label: D
options.text: Pulmonary embolism with right heart strain

questions.explanation: Ans. C) Obesity

questions.text: You are seeing Mr. Whaley in the clinic today. He is a 67-year-old man with no past medical history. He has symptoms of heart failure with orthopnea and limited exercise tolerance. On a 12-lead electrocardiogram he has both PR prolongation and multifocal premature ventricular contractions. Echocardiogram shows dilated left ventricular size and reduced function. Endomyocardial biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Cardiac sarcoidosis

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to your office requesting to be taken off of his antiepileptic drugs. He was in an automobile accident at the age of 12, resulting in significant head trauma. He was in a medically induced coma for 6 weeks and had intracranial edema with generalized tonic-clonic seizures at that time. These persisted for several years afterward. The last seizure he is aware of occurred at the age of 18 and was generalized. He continues to take valproic acid 1000 mg bid. On physical examination, he demonstrates normal cognition and affect. He has ongoing focal weakness involving his left lower extremity with spasticity. You refer him for a sleep-deprived electroencephalogram, which shows no evidence of focal abnormalities. Which of the following factors is of greatest concern regarding his risk of recurrent seizures?
questions.correct_answer: A. Focal defect on neurologic examination
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Focal defect on neurologic examination:

questions.text: A 60 years old male, presents to you in the emergency department with acute-onset dysarthria and confusion. You make the diagnosis of stroke clinically. What is the next appropriate step?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) CT of the brain

questions.text: A 65 years old male, is in the clinic after recent discharge for an ischemic stroke. He was prescribed aspirin as a secondary prevention measure. How long does the platelet antiaggregating effect of aspirin last?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with 1 year of progressive memory loss. She has had difficulties with executive functioning especially over the last 6 months. You note that she has an ataxic gait and her family mentions that she has had worsening urinary incontinence as well. Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy. Which of the following is the most effective method of diagnosis of the likely etiology of her dementia?

options.label: C
options.text: Close observation after lumbar puncture and removal of 30–50 cc of cerebrospinal fluid

questions.correct_answer: C. Close observation after lumbar puncture and removal of 30–50 cc of cerebrospinal fluid
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Close observation after lumbar puncture and removal of 30–50 cc of cerebrospinal fluid

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with symptoms of tremor and a generalized feeling of slowing down. His tremor bothers him most on his left side. His past medical history is significant for depression, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He is taking fluoxetine 40 mg daily, lisinopril 40 mg daily, and atorvastatin 20 mg daily. On physical examination, he has a resting tremor with presence of cogwheel rigidity. When observing his gait, you note slow, shuffling steps with difficulty maneuvering to turn around. His facial features show decreased range of emotion and appears somewhat flat. Eye movements are full. Mental status examination shows normal mentation. You suspect Parkinson disease. Which of the following is the first choice of therapy?

options.label: D
options.text: Any of the above can be used

questions.correct_answer: D. Any of the above can be used
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Any of the above can be used

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial treatment for Parkinson's disease should be tailored to the individual patient, considering various factors such as age, disease severity, comorbidities, and patient preferences. All three options (levodopa-carbidopa, dopamine agonists, and MAO-B inhibitors) are potential first-line therapies
  • ➤ The initial treatment for Parkinson's disease should be tailored to the individual patient, considering various factors such as age, disease severity, comorbidities, and patient preferences.
  • ➤ All three options (levodopa-carbidopa, dopamine agonists, and MAO-B inhibitors) are potential first-line therapies

questions.text: You are seeing a patient with a clinical syndrome suggesting Huntington disease (HD). He is inquiring about genetic testing. Which of the following is true regarding the genetic basis of HD?

options.label: A
options.text: HD is sporadic and not genetically based.

options.label: B
options.text: HD is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the aTTR gene.

options.label: C
options.text: HD is caused by an increase in polyglutamine repeats in the huntingtin gene.

options.label: D
options.text: HD is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene

questions.correct_answer: C. HD is caused by an increase in polyglutamine repeats in the huntingtin gene.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by an expanded CAG repeat in the HTT gene, leading to an abnormal polyglutamine tract in the huntingtin protein. Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis in individuals with suspected HD.

questions.text: Strokes can be divided into hemorrhagic and ischemic types with subtypes within those types. Which subtype of stroke has the strongest association with cognitive impairment and vascular dementia?
questions.correct_answer: D. Ischemic stroke, small vessel subtype
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ischemic stroke, small vessel subtype

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Small vessel ischemic strokes (lacunar strokes) are strongly associated with the development of vascular dementia due to their cumulative effect on subcortical structures, leading to cognitive impairment over time.
  • ➤ Small vessel ischemic strokes
  • ➤ vascular dementia

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with fatigue, dark urine in the morning, and shortness of breath. She has a history of recurrent venous thrombosis. Her labs show hemoglobin of 8.5 g/dL, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and low haptoglobin. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following flow cytometry findings will be seen?

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells

options.label: B
options.text: Increased CD19 and CD20 on lymphocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased CD4/CD8 ratio on T cells

options.label: D
options.text: Increased expression of CD5 on B cells

questions.correct_answer: A. Absence of CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Absence of CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In PNH , flow cytometry will reveal the absence of CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells, confirming the diagnosis of this hemolytic disorder.
  • ➤ PNH
  • ➤ absence of CD55 and CD59

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a long-standing history of asthma, comes to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath typical of her asthma exacerbations after visiting a friend’s who had seven cats in the house. On examination, she has diffuse bilateral polyphonic wheezes and is using accessory muscles to breathe. Her initial arterial blood gas on room air shows a pH of 7.34, PaCO2 of 32 mmHg, and PaO2 of 48 mmHg. After placing her on 40% oxygen by face mask, a repeat PaO2 is 200 mmHg and PaCO2 is 32 mmHg. The most likely cause of her initial hypoxemia was:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ventilation-perfusion mismatch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of hypoxemia in asthma is V/Q mismatch. V/Q mismatch responds well to supplemental oxygen, as demonstrated by the significant improvement in PaO2 in this patient. Recognizing the underlying mechanism of hypoxemia is crucial for appropriate management of respiratory conditions.
  • ➤ The most common cause of hypoxemia in asthma is V/Q mismatch.
  • ➤ V/Q mismatch responds well to supplemental oxygen, as demonstrated by the significant improvement in PaO2 in this patient.
  • ➤ Recognizing the underlying mechanism of hypoxemia is crucial for appropriate management of respiratory conditions.

questions.text: A 58-year-old quarry worker presents for evaluation because of an abnormal chest radiograph that was obtained by his primary care physician to investigate a chronic cough. The radiograph shows poorly defined upper lobe nodules, as well as enlarged hilar lymph nodes with eggshell calcifications. A purified protein derivative (PPD) was placed by the primary care physician, and it is positive in your office 2 days later. Which of the following is likely true about this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: False-positive PPDs are common in patients exposed to silicate dust.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient likely has active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) and needs to be isolated immediately.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient likely has latent TB and given the possibility of underlying silicosis he should be treated for a longer period of time.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient needs an urgent surgical biopsy to exclude active TB and diagnose the cause of the lung disease.

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient likely has latent TB and given the possibility of underlying silicosis he should be treated for a longer period of time.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The patient likely has latent TB and given the possibility of underlying silicosis he should be treated for a longer period of time.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Silicosis increases the risk of developing active TB. A positive PPD in a patient with silicosis warrants careful evaluation for active TB and consideration for prolonged LTBI treatment. Management should involve both pulmonologists and infectious disease specialists.
  • ➤ Silicosis increases the risk of developing active TB.
  • ➤ A positive PPD in a patient with silicosis warrants careful evaluation for active TB and consideration for prolonged LTBI treatment.
  • ➤ Management should involve both pulmonologists and infectious disease specialists.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a long history of cigarette smoking comes to see you for a 4-month history of progressive shortness of breath and dyspnea on exertion. The symptoms have been indolent, with no recent worsening. He denies fever, chest pain, or hemoptysis. He has a daily cough of 3–6 tablespoons of yellow phlegm. The patient says he has not seen a physician for over 10 years. Physical examination is notable for normal vital signs, a prolonged expiratory phase, scattered rhonchi, elevated jugular venous pulsation, and moderate pedal edema. Hematocrit is 49%. Which of the following therapies is most likely to prolong his survival?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LTOT (Long-term oxygen therapy)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LTOT is the only therapy proven to improve survival in patients with COPD and chronic hypoxemia. Other medications like bronchodilators and inhaled corticosteroids can improve symptoms and quality of life but do not directly impact survival.
  • ➤ LTOT is the only therapy proven to improve survival in patients with COPD and chronic hypoxemia.
  • ➤ Other medications like bronchodilators and inhaled corticosteroids can improve symptoms and quality of life but do not directly impact survival.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents with several months of dry cough, with worsening dyspnea on exertion. She is a non-smoker. In addition to her respiratory complaints, she notes worsening fatigue, intermittent low-grade fevers, and aches in her thighs and lower back. She has a history of Raynaud syndrome in the past and also notes severe dry skin with cracking on the sides of her thumbs and index fingers over the last month that she attributes to doing the dishes more frequently at home. Chest CT reveals diffuse subpleural, symmetric, ground glass, and reticular opacities with perhaps some early traction bronchiectasis at the bases. Which of the following would most likely yield the correct diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage and transbronchial biopsies

options.label: C
options.text: Serologies for anti-synthetase antibodies including Jo-1

options.label: D
options.text: Serum precipitins against common environmental exposures such as thermophilic bacteria and bird antigens

questions.correct_answer: C. Serologies for anti-synthetase antibodies including Jo-1
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serologies for anti-synthetase antibodies including Jo-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antisynthetase syndrome is a rare but important cause of interstitial lung disease. Recognizing the constellation of symptoms and findings (ILD, Raynaud's phenomenon, mechanic's hands, myalgias) can lead to early diagnosis and treatment. Serologic testing for anti-synthetase antibodies, including anti-Jo-1, is crucial in confirming the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Antisynthetase syndrome is a rare but important cause of interstitial lung disease.
  • ➤ Recognizing the constellation of symptoms and findings (ILD, Raynaud's phenomenon, mechanic's hands, myalgias) can lead to early diagnosis and treatment.
  • ➤ Serologic testing for anti-synthetase antibodies, including anti-Jo-1, is crucial in confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is evaluated for dyspnea on exertion that has progressively worsened over a period of 10 months. He has a 50 pack-year history of tobacco, quitting 10 years ago. On physical examination, has a resting oxygen saturation of 94%. After ambulation of 100 m, his oxygen saturation drops to 84%. His lung examination shows diffuse end-inspiratory crackles throughout both lungs. His total lung capacity is 72% predicted, residual volume is 68% predicted, and diffusing capacity is 60% predicted. The chest CT is shown below. Serologic workup for autoimmune disease is unremarkable, and thorough history yields no exposures that would lead to these findings. Given the likely diagnosis, What is the expected finding on surgical pathology?

options.label: B
options.text: Loosely organized granulomatous inflammation and fibrosis

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a chronic, progressive lung disease with a poor prognosis. The diagnosis of IPF is based on a combination of clinical features, pulmonary function tests, and imaging findings suggestive of UIP. Surgical lung biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis and exclude other interstitial lung diseases. UIP on biopsy is the hallmark of IPF.
  • ➤ Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a chronic, progressive lung disease with a poor prognosis.
  • ➤ The diagnosis of IPF is based on a combination of clinical features, pulmonary function tests, and imaging findings suggestive of UIP.
  • ➤ Surgical lung biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis and exclude other interstitial lung diseases.
  • ➤ UIP on biopsy is the hallmark of IPF.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a body mass index of 32 has recently been diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea with an apnea-hypopnea index of 13 per hour. He does not have a history of snoring. He presents to the clinic for follow-up because he has tried wearing continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) at home but has not felt comfortable with it. He asks if there are other potential treatment options for his sleep apnea. Which of the following would be a possible alternative therapy?

options.label: D
options.text: Upper airway neurostimulation is the preferred treatment of mild sleep apnea in patients who have failed CPAP therapy.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) An oral appliance.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The choice of OSA treatment depends on the severity of the condition (AHI) and the patient's individual preferences and tolerance to different therapies. In mild OSA, oral appliances are a good alternative for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP. For moderate to severe OSA, other options like upper airway neurostimulation or, in specific cases, bariatric surgery may be considered.
  • ➤ The choice of OSA treatment depends on the severity of the condition (AHI) and the patient's individual preferences and tolerance to different therapies.
  • ➤ In mild OSA, oral appliances are a good alternative for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.
  • ➤ For moderate to severe OSA, other options like upper airway neurostimulation or, in specific cases, bariatric surgery may be considered.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath and chest discomfort. He worked in shipbuilding for 30 years and retired 10 years ago. Gives a history of significant weight loss around 5-6kg in a span of 6 months. His chest X-ray shows pleural thickening and a right-sided pleural effusion. A CT scan reveals pleural plaques. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mesothelioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure and typically presents with pleural thickening , pleural effusions , and pleural plaques on imaging. This distinguishes it from other pulmonary diseases caused by occupational exposures.
  • ➤ Mesothelioma
  • ➤ asbestos exposure
  • ➤ pleural thickening
  • ➤ pleural effusions
  • ➤ pleural plaques

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has a history of splenectomy following trauma at the age of 20. He received appropriate vaccinations immediately after his trauma but has not had any medical care for more than 10 years. He is homeless. He presents to the emergency department with a fever of 102.3°F (39.1°C), blood pressure of 70/40, heart rate of 130 beats/min respiratory rate of 30 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. What is the best initial antibiotic therapy for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ceftriaxone and vancomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In asplenic patients with suspected sepsis , empiric antibiotic therapy should target encapsulated organisms . Ceftriaxone and vancomycin provide broad-spectrum coverage for these pathogens, including resistant Gram-positive organisms.
  • ➤ sepsis
  • ➤ encapsulated organisms
  • ➤ Ceftriaxone and vancomycin

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a past medical history of alcoholic cirrhosis presented with 3 days of right calf pain, chills, fevers, malaise, and a bullous rash on the right lower extremity after a meal of crab cakes and oysters as shown in image below. He presents to the emergency department with a fever of 39.1°C (102.3°F), blood pressure of 85/50, heart rate of 130 beats/min, respiratory rate of 30 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. What antibiotics should you initiate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Doxycycline and ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with cirrhosis who present with sepsis after consuming shellfish, consider Vibrio vulnificus infection. Empiric therapy should include doxycycline and ceftriaxone for optimal coverage.
  • ➤ cirrhosis
  • ➤ Vibrio vulnificus
  • ➤ doxycycline
  • ➤ ceftriaxone

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is traveling to Kenya for a safari. She has no past medical history and is not taking any other medications. All of the following may be recommended for prophylaxis against malaria for this patient EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For travelers to chloroquine-resistant regions such as Kenya, options for malaria prophylaxis include atovaquone-proguanil , doxycycline , or mefloquine . Chloroquine is ineffective due to widespread resistance in these areas.
  • ➤ chloroquine-resistant regions
  • ➤ atovaquone-proguanil
  • ➤ doxycycline
  • ➤ mefloquine
  • ➤ Chloroquine

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman presents with 3 days of fever and 1 day of severe pain in her left knee to the point where she can no longer stand. She has no past medical history. She is not sexually active. On examination, her temperature is 38.3°C. Her heart rate is 100 beats/min, with blood pressure of 128/75 mm/Hg. Her left knee is tender, with erythema and a palpable effusion. Her cardiac, lung, and abdominal examinations are all normal. Which of the following should you do?

options.label: A
options.text: Draw blood cultures and perform joint aspiration.

options.label: B
options.text: Draw blood cultures, perform an x-ray of the left knee, and initiate vancomycin.

options.label: C
options.text: Draw blood cultures, perform joint aspiration, and initiate vancomycin.

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate vancomycin and perform an x-ray of the left knee.

questions.correct_answer: C. Draw blood cultures, perform joint aspiration, and initiate vancomycin.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Draw blood cultures, perform joint aspiration, and initiate vancomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with a swollen, erythematous, and painful joint with fever, the priority is to perform joint aspiration to confirm septic arthritis and initiate empiric antibiotics like vancomycin to cover likely pathogens such as Staphylococcus aureus . Blood cultures should also be drawn to assess for bacteremia.
  • ➤ perform joint aspiration
  • ➤ septic arthritis
  • ➤ vancomycin
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman with dementia has been living in a nursing home for 5 years. She was seen by her primary care provider for evaluation of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. At that time, a stool sample was positive by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) confirms the diagnosis, and she was treated with oral metronidazole with some improvement in her symptoms. However, she has had five loose bowel movements per day starting 4 days ago and now has abdominal tenderness. Stool PCR remains positive. Colonoscopy was done and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Oral vancomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection , oral vancomycin is the treatment of choice, especially after metronidazole failure. In cases of multiple recurrences, fecal microbiota transplantation may be considered.
  • ➤ recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection
  • ➤ oral vancomycin
  • ➤ fecal microbiota transplantation

questions.text: A 20-year-old female college student with no past medical history presents with 3 days of fever, headache, and agitation. On presentation to the emergency department, she experiences a seizure. On examination, she has a blood pressure of 120/70, heart rate of 90 beats/min, and respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min. Her temperature is 38.3°C. She does not respond verbally to any questions or follow any commands. Her strength is intact in her upper and lower extremities and her reflexes are normal. Examination of her cerebrospinal fluid demonstrates a white blood cell count of 15 cells/μL, a red blood cell count of 500 cells/μL, glucose of 60, and protein of 100. While awaiting further tests, what treatment could you initiate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acyclovir IV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with suspected HSV encephalitis , which is suggested by CSF findings of lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated RBCs, and altered mental status, early initiation of IV acyclovir is critical while awaiting confirmatory testing like PCR.
  • ➤ HSV encephalitis
  • ➤ IV acyclovir

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman with a recently worsening tremor. She notes that it predominantly affects her hands and is worse with action such as trying to eat. It is not present at rest. It is improved by drinking 1–2 beers. She has no other symptoms. On examination, her resting heart rate is 52 beats/min with normal vital signs otherwise. Which of the following is the best initial therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primidone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with essential tremor who also have bradycardia , primidone is a better choice for initial therapy than propranolol, as it avoids the risk of worsening the bradycardia.
  • ➤ essential tremor
  • ➤ bradycardia
  • ➤ primidone

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman came to the emergency department with fever and sore throat. On examination, she has extensive submandibular and cervical swelling present. Patient’s oral cavity is shown below. A rapid strep test is negative. The patient is at risk for which of the following complications of this disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Myocarditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphtheria presents with a pseudomembrane in the throat and can lead to serious complications like myocarditis due to the systemic effects of the diphtheria toxin. Prompt recognition and treatment with diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics are essential.
  • ➤ Diphtheria
  • ➤ pseudomembrane
  • ➤ myocarditis

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents for neurologic evaluation after experiencing a severe burn on the palm of her right hand. She had placed her hand onto the hot surface of a smooth electric range. She did not feel the burn when it occurred and only when she picked her hand up did she notice the burn. After that, it was discovered that the patient unknowingly has bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in both hands. However, she does have touch and vibratory sense. Mapping of her loss of sensation shows decreased pain sensation in the nape of her neck, shoulders, and upper arms as well in a cape-like distribution. Deep tendon reflexes are absent at the biceps and triceps, and there is visible muscle wasting of the right biceps and shoulder musculature. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Syringomyelia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Syringomyelia is a condition characterized by a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord, causing a cape-like distribution of sensory loss and muscle weakness/atrophy. It's important to recognize the classic presentation of syringomyelia and differentiate it from other spinal cord disorders. MRI is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing syringomyelia.
  • ➤ Syringomyelia is a condition characterized by a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord, causing a cape-like distribution of sensory loss and muscle weakness/atrophy.
  • ➤ It's important to recognize the classic presentation of syringomyelia and differentiate it from other spinal cord disorders.
  • ➤ MRI is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing syringomyelia.

questions.text: You are seeing a 23-year-old woman who is 3 months pregnant and is sexually active. She has been experiencing dysuria and vaginal discharge. Gram stain of her vaginal discharge is shown in the image below. She has no known medication allergies. Which of the following is the most reasonable medical regimen for the treatment of her infection?

options.label: B
options.text: Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM and azithromycin 1 g orally once

options.label: C
options.text: Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM once and doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days

options.label: D
options.text: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily for 10 days

questions.correct_answer: B. Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM and azithromycin 1 g orally once
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM and azithromycin 1 g orally once

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pregnant women with Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, the treatment regimen should include Ceftriaxone and Azithromycin , which are both safe in pregnancy and cover the risk of co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis .
  • ➤ Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • ➤ Ceftriaxone
  • ➤ Azithromycin
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and chronic low back pain presents to the clinic for follow-up. His physical examination is unremarkable with no edema or jugular venous distension. Recent laboratory testing shows a decreased glomerular filtration rate of 55 mL/min/1.73 m2. His hemoglobin A1c is 5.4%. He is currently on metformin, naproxen, and hydrochlorothiazide. What medication change could help slow his progression of chronic kidney disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Substitute lisinopril for hydrochlorothiazide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors or ARBs are essential in slowing CKD progression in patients with hypertension and/or diabetes.
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors or ARBs are essential in slowing CKD progression in patients with hypertension and/or diabetes.
  • ➤ In this case, substituting lisinopril for hydrochlorothiazide would provide better blood pressure control and renal protection.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with rapidly progressive weakness over 2 days, including difficulty standing and lifting his arms. He also reports tingling in his hands and feet and sharp pains in his shoulders and spine. His blood pressure has dropped from 138/82 to 92/50, and he has absent deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities. Which of the following features would most commonly accompany this patient’s history?

options.label: A
options.text: A diagnosis of “walking pneumonia” that was treated with azithromycin 2 weeks prior to presentation

options.label: B
options.text: An acute diarrheal illness 2 weeks prior to presentation

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of a massive mediastinal lymphadenopathy on chest radiograph

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of a monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance on laboratory testing

questions.correct_answer: B. An acute diarrheal illness 2 weeks prior to presentation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) An acute diarrheal illness 2 weeks prior to presentation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) often follows an acute diarrheal illness and presents with rapidly progressive weakness, areflexia, and autonomic dysfunction. Early recognition and management are crucial to prevent respiratory failure.
  • ➤ Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS)
  • ➤ acute diarrheal illness

questions.text: A 33-year-old previously healthy woman presents to the emergency department with malaise, confusion, and fever of 37.8°C (100.1°F). She had no preceding diarrheal illness. CT of the head is unremarkable. She is found to have platelets of 13,000/cu, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, and creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows pH 5.0, protein 1+, and 11 red blood cells/high-powered field. Which of the following laboratory findings would be expected with her diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ADAMSTS13 <10%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TTP is a medical emergency characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and organ dysfunction. A low ADAMTS13 level (<10%) is a key diagnostic finding in TTP. Prompt recognition and treatment with plasma exchange are crucial to improve outcomes.
  • ➤ TTP is a medical emergency characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and organ dysfunction.
  • ➤ A low ADAMTS13 level (<10%) is a key diagnostic finding in TTP.
  • ➤ Prompt recognition and treatment with plasma exchange are crucial to improve outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following medications used to treat multiple sclerosis is highly effective and targets CD20 on the surface of mature B cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ocrelizumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ocrelizumab is a highly effective disease-modifying therapy for multiple sclerosis that targets CD20 on B cells, leading to B cell depletion and a reduction in disease activity. It is important to understand the different mechanisms of action of various MS medications to make informed treatment decisions.
  • ➤ Ocrelizumab is a highly effective disease-modifying therapy for multiple sclerosis that targets CD20 on B cells, leading to B cell depletion and a reduction in disease activity.
  • ➤ It is important to understand the different mechanisms of action of various MS medications to make informed treatment decisions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is evaluated for severe headaches that have occurred several times over the last 5–7 years. He describes the headache as occurring behind his left eye and coming on suddenly. The headaches have a stabbing quality and are associated with tearing of his eye and nasal congestion. He says the pain is a “12” out of 10 when it occurs, and he finds that he cannot even sit still due to pain. The headaches last about 20 minutes and then subside. He says that the headaches always seem to occur around 5 AM, but he can go months without having any headache at all. He has a difficult time identifying a trigger for the headaches. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

options.label: D
options.text: Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headaches with conjunctival injection and tearing

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cluster headache

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cluster headaches are a rare but debilitating primary headache disorder. They present with severe, unilateral, stabbing pain around the eye or temple, often with autonomic symptoms. Recognizing the characteristic features is essential for prompt diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Cluster headaches are a rare but debilitating primary headache disorder.
  • ➤ They present with severe, unilateral, stabbing pain around the eye or temple, often with autonomic symptoms.
  • ➤ Recognizing the characteristic features is essential for prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male college student presents with profound fatigue, foot spasms, cramps, and sustained muscle contractions. Laboratory evaluation reveals hypokalemia (2.8 mEq/L), hypochloremia (90 mEq/L), and metabolic alkalosis (bicarbonate of 30 mmol/L), with normal sodium and magnesium levels. Urine chloride is elevated, and diuretic abuse is ruled out. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gitelman syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gitelman syndrome presents with hypokalemia , hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis , normal or elevated urine chloride, and muscle cramps due to defective reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. It is an inherited disorder often diagnosed in young adults with chronic electrolyte disturbances.
  • ➤ Gitelman syndrome
  • ➤ hypokalemia
  • ➤ hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with malaise, confusion, and headache. Blood pressure is found to be 220/105. Physical examination is notable for skin thickening of the arms and legs, facial telangiectasias, and decreased oral aperture. Laboratory studies show a creatinine of 3.5 mg/dL, hemoglobin of 7.0 g/dL, platelets of 75,000/dL, lactate dehydrogenase of 700. What is the appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Captopril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency requiring prompt recognition and treatment. ACE inhibitors are the cornerstone of treatment for SRC. Early diagnosis and aggressive blood pressure control are crucial to improve outcomes.
  • ➤ Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency requiring prompt recognition and treatment.
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors are the cornerstone of treatment for SRC.
  • ➤ Early diagnosis and aggressive blood pressure control are crucial to improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with a history of colon cancer treated with resection and chemotherapy 2 years earlier is admitted to the hospital after routine lab work at her primary care physician’s office showed a blood urea nitrogen of 65 mg/dL and a creatinine of 4.5 mg/dL. She reports mild fatigue and recent lower back pain, but otherwise feels well. She does admit to recent nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use but has not taken more than the recommended quantity. Aside from stopping the NSAID and avoidance of nephrotoxins, which of the following studies should be the next step?

options.label: A
options.text: CT of the abdomen/pelvis with oral contrast

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ultrasound of the abdomen/kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with acute kidney injury (AKI) , particularly those with a history of malignancy, an ultrasound is the preferred initial study to evaluate for obstructive causes of renal impairment. This modality is non-invasive, safe, and does not expose the kidneys to further nephrotoxins.
  • ➤ acute kidney injury (AKI)
  • ➤ ultrasound
  • ➤ obstructive causes

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of chronic hepatitis C presents with fatigue, edema, and dark urine. Laboratory studies reveal hematuria, proteinuria, and reduced serum complement levels. A renal biopsy is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is associated with chronic hepatitis C and presents with proteinuria , hematuria , low complement levels , and characteristic tram-track changes on renal biopsy.
  • ➤ Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN)
  • ➤ chronic hepatitis C
  • ➤ proteinuria
  • ➤ hematuria
  • ➤ low complement levels
  • ➤ tram-track

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with known chronic alcohol use, presents with two episodes of hematemesis. He recently sustained a fall and injured his knee. He has been taking ibuprofen several times a day for the last week for pain control. His initial hemoglobin is 10 g/dL. He receives 2 L of IV fluid and undergoes an urgent upper endoscopy. All of the following are true about his risk of rebleeding without intervention EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: A clean-based ulcer is associated with a low risk (3–5%) of rebleeding.

options.label: B
options.text: Adherent clots covering the ulcer base have a 90% risk of rebleeding.

options.label: C
options.text: Flat pigmented spots covering the ulcer base have a 10% risk of rebleeding.

options.label: D
options.text: When a fibrin plug is seen protruding from a vessel wall in the base of an ulcer, (so-called sentinel clot or visible vessel), the risk of rebleeding from the ulcer is 40%.

questions.correct_answer: B. Adherent clots covering the ulcer base have a 90% risk of rebleeding.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  Adherent clots covering the ulcer base have a 90% risk of rebleeding.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The risk of rebleeding in peptic ulcers varies based on endoscopic findings, with clean-based ulcers having the lowest risk and visible vessels having a moderate risk. Adherent clots typically have a lower rebleeding risk (20-30%) than visible vessels and benefit from therapeutic intervention to reduce the risk further.
  • ➤ rebleeding
  • ➤ Adherent clots
  • ➤ lower rebleeding risk

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a long history of abdominal pain, heartburn, and dyspepsia has an esophagogastroduodenoscopy to evaluate for peptic ulcer disease. No gastric or duodenal ulcers are found, but there are tongues of reddish mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction into the esophagus. Biopsies of these areas demonstrate columnar metaplasia. All of the following statements regarding this diagnosis are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Finding high-grade dysplasia mandates further intervention.

options.label: B
options.text: High-dose proton pump inhibitor therapy will likely cause regression of the mucosal abnormalities.

options.label: C
options.text: The incidence of these lesions has increased in the era of potent acid suppression.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient has a high risk of coexisting cancer.

questions.correct_answer: B. High-dose proton pump inhibitor therapy will likely cause regression of the mucosal abnormalities.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  High-dose proton pump inhibitor therapy will likely cause regression of the mucosal abnormalities.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Barrett's esophagus is a condition where columnar metaplasia replaces the normal squamous epithelium in the esophagus due to chronic GERD. While PPIs help control symptoms, they do not reverse metaplasia. The presence of high-grade dysplasia mandates further intervention due to the high risk of progression to esophageal adenocarcinoma.
  • ➤ Barrett's esophagus
  • ➤ columnar metaplasia
  • ➤ PPIs
  • ➤ high-grade dysplasia

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman who presents with recurrent episodes of chest discomfort at rest. She denies exertional dyspnea and reports that occasionally her pain is relieved with antacids. She works as a health care consultant and has frequent stressful battles with doctors and hospitals. An exercise cardiac stress test does not reveal any evidence of inducible ischemia. She has a barium swallow shown below. You suspect that she has diffuse esophageal spasm. Which of the following findings on esophageal manometry would support that diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Contractions in the distal esophagus with short latency relative to the time of the pharyngeal contraction

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) contraction and absent peristalsis with substantial fluid pressurization of the esophageal body

options.label: D
options.text: Impaired LES contraction and absent peristalsis with no fluid pressurization of the esophageal body

questions.correct_answer: A. Contractions in the distal esophagus with short latency relative to the time of the pharyngeal contraction
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  Contractions in the distal esophagus with short latency relative to the time of the pharyngeal contraction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse esophageal spasm is diagnosed with esophageal manometry , which reveals simultaneous or premature contractions in the distal esophagus. These uncoordinated contractions can cause chest pain that mimics cardiac ischemia, as well as dysphagia.
  • ➤ Diffuse esophageal spasm
  • ➤ esophageal manometry
  • ➤ simultaneous or premature contractions

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated by her primary care physician for diffuse, crampy abdominal pain. She reports that she has had abdominal pain for the last several years, but it is getting worse and is now associated with intermittent diarrhea without flatulence. This does not wake her at night. Stools do not float and are not hard to flush. She has not noted any worsening with specific foods, but she does have occasional rashes on her lower legs. She has lost about 6 kg over the last year. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this point?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  Measurement of antiendomysial antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young patient with abdominal pain , diarrhea , weight loss , and rashes suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis , the initial step is to test for celiac disease using antiendomysial or anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies .
  • ➤ abdominal pain
  • ➤ diarrhea
  • ➤ weight loss
  • ➤ rashes
  • ➤ dermatitis herpetiformis
  • ➤ celiac disease
  • ➤ antiendomysial or anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies

questions.text: A 59-year-old female develops acute diverticulitis and requires hospitalization for IV antibiotics. She has a CT scan that does not show evidence of abscess perforation, stricture, or fistula, and she improves in about a week. Which of the following should be undertaken to prevent further symptomatic disease?
questions.correct_answer: D. Initiation of a high-fiber diet
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)  Initiation of a high-fiber diet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To reduce the risk of recurrent diverticulitis , patients should adopt a high-fiber diet , which can help improve colonic motility and decrease the likelihood of diverticula becoming inflamed. Avoidance of nuts and seeds is no longer recommended
  • ➤ diverticulitis
  • ➤ high-fiber diet

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman who was previously incarcerated has an area of induration that measures 15 mm 72 hours after a skin test with tuberculin purified protein derivative (PPD). A positive PPD skin test for Mycobacterium tuberculosis represents which type of immune reaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  Delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive PPD skin test for Mycobacterium tuberculosis represents a Type IV delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, involving T-cell mediated immunity and typically appearing 48-72 hours after the test.
  • ➤ PPD skin test
  • ➤ Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • ➤ Type IV delayed-type hypersensitivity
  • ➤ T-cell mediated immunity

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic with intermittent flushing, diarrhea, headaches, and a new skin rash of several months’ duration. He has noticed that his symptoms of diarrhea and flushing tend to worsen if he takes ibuprofen to treat his headaches. On examination, he has a palpable spleen and cervical lymphadenopathy. Serum tryptase is elevated at 35 ng/mL. His skin rash is shown below. A diagnostic skin biopsy is performed. What histological findings are most likely to be noted on the skin biopsy?

options.label: B
options.text: Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systemic mastocytosis is a rare disorder characterized by the abnormal proliferation and accumulation of mast cells. It can present with a variety of symptoms, including flushing, diarrhea, headaches, and skin rash.
  • ➤ Systemic mastocytosis is a rare disorder characterized by the abnormal proliferation and accumulation of mast cells.
  • ➤ It can present with a variety of symptoms, including flushing, diarrhea, headaches, and skin rash.
  • ➤ Elevated serum tryptase levels and the presence of multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells on skin biopsy are key diagnostic features.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of psoriasis presents to the clinic for a follow-up appointment. He has been treated with infliximab about a year. Since his last infusion of infliximab, he has been experiencing aching in his muscles and joints and a new facial rash. On examination you note a raised erythematous malar rash, but there is no synovitis in any joints and there is no weakness on neurologic examination. Laboratory testing shows a positive anti-nuclear antibody at a titer of 1:320. Which specific autoantibody is most likely to be present?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anti-histone antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drug-induced lupus erythematosus is a potential complication of certain medications, including TNF inhibitors like infliximab. It typically presents with muscle and joint aches, skin rash, and a positive ANA. Anti-histone antibodies are highly specific for DILE and are the most likely autoantibody to be present in this case.
  • ➤ Drug-induced lupus erythematosus is a potential complication of certain medications, including TNF inhibitors like infliximab.
  • ➤ It typically presents with muscle and joint aches, skin rash, and a positive ANA.
  • ➤ Anti-histone antibodies are highly specific for DILE and are the most likely autoantibody to be present in this case.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with depression and chronic migraine headaches reports several years of dry mouth and dry eyes. Her primary complaint is that she can no longer eat her favorite crackers, although she does report photosensitivity and eye burning on further questioning. She has no other associated symptoms. Examination shows dry, erythematous, sticky oral mucosa. All of the following tests are likely to be positive in this patient EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Scl-70 antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease that causes dryness of the eyes and mouth. It can be associated with other symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, and skin rash. The diagnosis is based on clinical features, autoantibody testing (anti-Ro/SS-A, anti-La/SS-B), and objective measures of dryness (Schirmer's test). Scl-70 antibody is not associated with Sjögren's syndrome and is more specific for scleroderma.
  • ➤ Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease that causes dryness of the eyes and mouth.
  • ➤ It can be associated with other symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, and skin rash.
  • ➤ The diagnosis is based on clinical features, autoantibody testing (anti-Ro/SS-A, anti-La/SS-B), and objective measures of dryness (Schirmer's test).
  • ➤ Scl-70 antibody is not associated with Sjögren's syndrome and is more specific for scleroderma.

questions.text: A patient with primary Sjögren syndrome that was diagnosed 6 years ago and treated with tear replacement for symptomatic relief notes continued parotid swelling for the last 3 months. She has also noted enlarging posterior cervical lymph nodes. Evaluation shows leukopenia and low C4 complement levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)  Lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with primary Sjögren syndrome have an increased risk of developing non-Hodgkin lymphoma , particularly when they exhibit persistent parotid gland swelling, lymphadenopathy, and immune changes such as leukopenia and low complement levels . Close monitoring for signs of lymphoma is essential in these patients.
  • ➤ primary Sjögren syndrome
  • ➤ non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • ➤ leukopenia
  • ➤ low complement levels

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with pain and swelling in his right knee and left ankle. He also reports dysuria and eye redness that began two weeks ago. He recently had an episode of urethritis but did not seek treatment. There is no history of trauma. Examination reveals conjunctival injection and tenderness of the affected joints. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)  Reactive arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reactive arthritis is a post-infectious autoimmune syndrome often triggered by Chlamydia urethritis and presents with the triad of arthritis, urethritis , and conjunctivitis . It is crucial to recognize the association with prior infections to guide appropriate management.
  • ➤ Reactive arthritis
  • ➤ post-infectious autoimmune syndrome
  • ➤ Chlamydia urethritis
  • ➤ arthritis, urethritis
  • ➤ conjunctivitis

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is evaluated for 1 year of recurrent episodes of bilateral ear swelling. The ear is painful during these events, and the right ear has become floppy. He is otherwise healthy and reports no illicit habits. He works in an office, and his only sport is cricket on sundays. On examination, the left ear has a beefy red color and the pinna is tender and swollen; the earlobe appears minimally swollen but is neither red nor tender. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)  Relapsing polychondritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Relapsing polychondritis is a rare inflammatory disease that primarily affects cartilage. Recurrent episodes of painful ear swelling with potential cartilage damage are characteristic features. The diagnosis is often clinical, but biopsy may be needed in some cases. Treatment typically involves corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications.
  • ➤ Relapsing polychondritis is a rare inflammatory disease that primarily affects cartilage.
  • ➤ Recurrent episodes of painful ear swelling with potential cartilage damage are characteristic features.
  • ➤ The diagnosis is often clinical, but biopsy may be needed in some cases.
  • ➤ Treatment typically involves corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with right thumb and wrist pain that has worsened over several weeks. She has pain when she pinches her thumb against her other fingers. Her only other history is that she is a new mother with an 8-week-old infant at home. On physical examination, she has mild swelling and tenderness over the radial styloid process, and pain is elicited when she places her thumb in her palm and grasps it with her fingers. A Phalen maneuver is negative. Which condition is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  De Quervain tenosynovitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ De Quervain tenosynovitis is a common overuse injury that can occur in new mothers. Recognizing the characteristic symptoms and physical exam findings is crucial for prompt diagnosis and management. Treatment options include rest, splinting, NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, and in severe cases, surgery.
  • ➤ De Quervain tenosynovitis is a common overuse injury that can occur in new mothers.
  • ➤ Recognizing the characteristic symptoms and physical exam findings is crucial for prompt diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Treatment options include rest, splinting, NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, and in severe cases, surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man reports to his primary care physician that his wife has noted coarsening of his facial features over several years. In addition, he reports low libido and decreased energy. Physical examination shows frontal bossing and enlarged hands. An MRI confirms that he has a pituitary mass. Which of the following screening tests should be ordered to diagnose the cause of the mass?
questions.correct_answer: D. Serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) level
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with clinical features of acromegaly and a pituitary mass , the screening test of choice is serum IGF-1 , as it provides a more accurate reflection of growth hormone activity than a direct GH measurement.
  • ➤ acromegaly
  • ➤ pituitary mass
  • ➤ serum IGF-1
  • ➤ growth hormone

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has a pituitary adenoma on imaging that has extended directly superiorly and is compressing his optic chiasm. Which of the following visual field deficits is most likely present?
questions.correct_answer: C. Bitemporal hemianopia with superior defect
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Compression of the optic chiasm by a pituitary adenoma commonly leads to bitemporal hemianopia , a visual field defect affecting the temporal visual fields of both eyes due to damage to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.
  • ➤ optic chiasm
  • ➤ pituitary adenoma
  • ➤ bitemporal hemianopia
  • ➤ temporal visual fields

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for anxiety, palpitations, and diarrhea and found to have Graves disease. Before she begins therapy for her thyroid condition, she has an episode of acute chest pain and presents to the emergency department. Although a CT angiogram is ordered, the radiologist calls to notify the treating physician that this is potentially dangerous. Which of the following best explains the radiologist’s concern?

options.label: A
options.text: Iodinated contrast exposure in patients with Graves disease may exacerbate hyperthyroidism.

options.label: B
options.text: Pulmonary embolism is exceedingly rare in Graves disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Radiation exposure in patients with hyperthyroidism is associated with increased risk of subsequent malignancy.

options.label: D
options.text: Tachycardia with Graves disease limits the image quality of CT angiography and will not allow accurate assessment of pulmonary embolism

questions.correct_answer: A. Iodinated contrast exposure in patients with Graves disease may exacerbate hyperthyroidism.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  Iodinated contrast exposure in patients with Graves disease may exacerbate hyperthyroidism.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with Graves disease , exposure to iodinated contrast during procedures like CT angiography can exacerbate hyperthyroidism, potentially leading to thyroid storm . Careful consideration and alternative imaging methods may be necessary.
  • ➤ Graves disease
  • ➤ iodinated contrast
  • ➤ thyroid storm

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of medullary thyroid carcinoma presents with episodic palpitations, sweating, and severe hypertension that occurs unpredictably. Her father also had thyroid cancer and passed away from a sudden hypertensive crisis. Genetic testing shows a RET proto-oncogene mutation. Laboratory studies reveal elevated plasma normetanephrines and an adrenal mass on imaging. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parathyroid hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MEN 2A is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma , pheochromocytoma , and parathyroid hyperplasia , and is associated with RET proto-oncogene mutations . Family history and clinical findings guide the diagnosis.
  • ➤ MEN 2A
  • ➤ medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ parathyroid hyperplasia
  • ➤ RET proto-oncogene mutations

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with numbness and weakness in his legs and feet. On examination, you find that he is numb to the knees and has marked weakness in ankle dorsiflexion and plantar flexion. Two years ago, he developed diabetes, and last year, he was admitted when found to be profoundly hypothyroid. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly and appears to have a dark tan despite having no sun exposure recently. Which of the following tests will likely help make his diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serum protein electrophoresis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ POEMS syndrome is characterized by polyneuropathy , organomegaly , endocrinopathy , monoclonal gammopathy , and skin changes . Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) is essential for identifying the monoclonal protein that underlies this condition.
  • ➤ POEMS syndrome
  • ➤ polyneuropathy
  • ➤ organomegaly
  • ➤ endocrinopathy
  • ➤ monoclonal gammopathy
  • ➤ skin changes
  • ➤ Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP)
  • ➤ monoclonal protein

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the clinic to discuss contraception options. She has a history of mild hypertension that is well controlled on amlodipine 5 mg daily. She smokes about one pack of cigarettes per day. Her family history is notable for ovarian cancer in her grandmother and a stroke in her father. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for oral contraceptives?
questions.correct_answer: A. Age >35 combined with cigarette use
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  Age >35 combined with cigarette use

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) are absolutely contraindicated in women who are older than 35 and who smoke due to the increased risk of thromboembolism , myocardial infarction , and stroke .
  • ➤ Combined oral contraceptives (COCs)
  • ➤ absolutely contraindicated
  • ➤ older than 35
  • ➤ thromboembolism
  • ➤ myocardial infarction
  • ➤ stroke

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the clinic for his yearly visit. He complains of pain in his feet and ankles bilaterally that has been present for over a year. His past medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension treated with lisinopril and type 2 diabetes mellitus (hemoglobin A1c 10.3%). He lives alone and does not have any family that checks on him routinely. He works in a factory, frequently standing for most of the day, and recently the pain has limited his work capacity. He feels the pain in his feet has become debilitating and he is hoping for some relief to be able to return to work. Which of the following medications would be best for him?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)  Duloxetine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Duloxetine is an effective and well-tolerated treatment for diabetic peripheral neuropathy in older adults, with fewer side effects than tricyclic antidepressants. It provides both pain relief and mood stabilization, making it a preferred option in patients like this one with neuropathic pain .
  • ➤ Duloxetine
  • ➤ diabetic peripheral neuropathy
  • ➤ neuropathic pain

questions.text: An 80-year-old man with a history of hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide and metoprolol tartrate. He presents to your clinic with a complaint of fatigue over the past few weeks. On examination, the only notable finding is a heart rate of 40 beats/min. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus bradycardia with normal PR interval. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities including normal thyroid studies and hemoglobin. The next most reasonable step would be which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Stop metoprolol tartrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta-blockers are a common cause of bradycardia. In a patient with symptomatic bradycardia and a history of beta-blocker use, discontinuing the medication is the most reasonable initial step. If symptoms persist after medication discontinuation, further evaluation and consideration of pacemaker implantation may be necessary.
  • ➤ Beta-blockers are a common cause of bradycardia.
  • ➤ In a patient with symptomatic bradycardia and a history of beta-blocker use, discontinuing the medication is the most reasonable initial step.
  • ➤ If symptoms persist after medication discontinuation, further evaluation and consideration of pacemaker implantation may be necessary.
